Award.AwardTitle: Puzzles of homotopy algebras related to deformation theory
Award.AbstractNarration:
To every classical algebra (associative, commutative, Lie) one can assign its homotopy version. In a homotopy version, axioms of the original algebra hold only up to a homotopy and the corresponding homotopy operators are considered as a part of this algebraic structure. These homotopy operators are supposed to satisfy their own coherence laws also up to homotopy and so on. The PI continues his research on homotopy algebras related to Deligne's conjecture on Hochschild complexes and various generalizations of Kontsevich's formality theorem. The PI will continue his work on stable formality quasi-isomorphisms and their homotopy classes. The PI will continue his joint work with D. Tamarkin and B. Tsygan on homotopy calculus structure on Hochschild complexes and apply results to the algebraic index theorem for formal deformations. The PI (jointly with V. Ginzburg) is going to establish a link between homotopy calculus algebras and homotopy BV algebras and apply the results to deformation theory of Calabi-Yau algebras. Finally, the PI is going to investigate a higher categorical structure on homotopy algebras.

Homotopy algebras appear in various problems of algebraic topology, algebraic geometry, deformation theory, and mathematical physics. The PI's work on homotopy algebras is motivated by quantization: a process of constructing quantum versions of models of classical mechanics. The project will enhance our understanding of fundamental principles which underpin quantum theory and their links to other branches of mathematics. The PI works with graduate students and postdoctoral researchers, and runs research oriented seminars. The P.I. invites mathematicians from the US and from abroad to speak at the colloquium and at the algebra seminar at Temple University. Talks of invitees give graduate students an opportunity to be exposed to current problems in mathematics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Here is a colloquial description of the MAIN OUTCOMES of this project:

1) In 1999, a Fields medalist Maxim Kontsevich proposed a conjecture about a manifestation of the Grothendieck-Teichmueller Lie algebra grt in the extended moduli of algebraic varieties. The Lie algebra grt was introduced by (yet another Fields medalist) Vladimir Drinfeld in 1990 and it has links to the moduli of curves, theory of motives, and the absolute Galois group of rational numbers. The PI, jointly with C.L. Rogers and T.H. Willwacher, proved this conjecture and the proof of this conjecture was published in Annals of Mathematics in November of 2015.

2) Back in 1997, Maxim Kontsevich proposed a solution to a very hard problem of constructing a zig-zag of weak equivalences between the algebra of poydifferential operators and its cohomology. One of the consequences of Kontsevich's construction is a solution to the problem of deformation quantization. The PI has been working on a paper in which a complete description of all such solutions is given. A preliminary version of this paper is available on arXiv.org


3) Although homotopy algebras and their generalizations appear in constructions of string topology, rational homotopy theory, symplectic topology, deformation quantization and quantum field theory, it was not clear what higher categorial structure stands behind homotopy algebras. The PI, jointly with A. E. Hoffnung and C.L. Rogers, proposed a possible candidate for such a higher categorical structure. A paper devoted to this result was published in Advances in Mathematics.

BROADER IMPACTS:

The PI's PhD student Brian Paljug was partially supported by this grant. He defended his PhD thesis "Deformation complexes for algebraic operads and their applications." in April of 2015. The PI's current PhD student Geoffrey Schneider was also partially supported by this grant.

The PI served as a postdoctoral mentor for Alexander E. Hoffnung.

The PI participated in organzing seminars and conferences. He was also disseminating his research results by giving talks at seminars, colloquia and conferences. The PI has been serving as the Putnam coordinator at Temple University.
